original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares edge down on profit taking and selling pressure
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged down in mid day trade on Tuesday, on selling pressure and profit taking, an analyst said.

“The market is having a slow day and there is a downward trend pushed on selling pressures and profit taking as the market was picking up on debt optimization assurances,” Ranjan Ranatunga of First Capital Holdings said.

Sri Lanka’s banks said assurances has been received that the stability of the sector cannot be risked in a planned domestic debt overhaul, to make the defaulted debt sustainable under a program with the International Monetary Fund.
ASPI was down 0.29 percent or 25.50 points to 8,901.08, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was up 0.03 percent or 0.67 points to 2,594.11.
“A wait and see approach is still being utilized by investors because the Press Release was based on the Banking Association rather than from formal entity,” Ranatunga said.
“Turnover is slow and if the banking sector is stagnant then the entire market is stagnant,” Ranatunga said.
Top losers during mid day trade were Vallibel, Sampath Bank and Chevron Lubricants. (Colombo/May09/2023)
